Award.AwardTitle: Exploring Ionic Liquids for Low Temperature and Low Emission Water Desalination

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The availability of clean water has become one of the most critical problems facing society and the global economy in the 21st century. Oceans cover 71% of the planet and store approximately 97% of its water. Therefore, future water shortages could be alleviated through the development and deployment of more efficient and cost-effective technologies to desalinate seawater. Current commercial seawater desalination technologies are energy intensive and their operations require high-grade electricity. Recent studies have shown that a solvent-based desalination process, referred to as directional solvent extraction, can extract and release clean water from high salinity source waters using readily available sources of heat (e.g., solar energy, waste heat, etc.). The goal of this research project is to gain a better understanding of the underlying physical and chemical principles behind the directional solvent extraction process. The investigators will combine state-of-the-art computational modeling with the synthesis, characterization, and bench scale lab evaluation of new materials for the design and development of next-generation methods. Successful outcomes of this project will benefit society through efficient and cost-effective technologies to desalinate seawater. Further benefits to society will be achieved through student education and training including the mentoring of two doctoral students.

Current thermal and membrane-based seawater desalination technologies are energy intensive and costly. In contrast, a directional solvent extraction process could be operated using heat sources at temperatures as low 40 ËšC and without the need for a membrane. However, the availability of solvents with the right properties has remained a major impediment to the development and implementation of this technology. The comparatively low volatility, minimal toxicity, and architectural variability of ionic liquids have made them attractive as potential solvents for use in directional solvent extraction-based desalination. The goal of this research project is to better understand the solvation and phase behavior of ionic liquids in high salinity aqueous solutions. By combining molecular simulations with materials synthesis and characterization and bench scale desalination experiments, the investigators will identify the key structure-property relationships that govern the competing solubilities of ionic liquids with water and natural salt ions. Ultimately, the investigators will leverage this new knowledge in developing more energy-efficient and environmentally benign directional solvent extraction processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research outcomes that were generated from the National Science Foundation funded project CBET 2031431 relate directly to ascertaining the intramolecular forces responsible for solvation behavior, and the design, synthesis and evaluation of new fluid materials to establish a directional solvent extraction water desalination protocol. The development of solvent-based desalinations utilizing renewable energy or waste heat have the potential to transform current approaches to water purification, and the primary outcome of this project was the establishment of a basis for the development of an environmentally benign desalination technology. While small molecule-based simple organic fluids have an established track record as materials in energy and water related research and development, the comparatively low volatility, minimal toxicity, and architectural variability of task-specific ionic liquids (TSILs) have rendered this class of fluids attractive alternatives to conventional materials. The rational design of high performance, TSILs for energy efficient water desalinations and other applications calls for a thorough understanding of IL solvation physics with water and ions. The outcomes of this project provide the foundation for a fundamental understanding of the solvation dynamics and phase separation behavior of TSILs in aqueous saline solutions to predict and optimize their physical properties in a directional solvent extraction process. During the funding period, we sought to accomplish this task through the development of 1) high-fidelity force fields from first-principle calculations for TSILs that exhibit directional solubility for comparison to those that do not, 2) a predictive measure of directional solubilities involving water, natural salt ions and TSILs using MC and MD simulations, and 3) design, synthesize and characterize ILs bearing directional solubility performance properties in order to merge our computational and experimental results. Specifically, significant accomplishments over the course of the funding period include:

  1. The discovery that a mixed IL system comprised of a single N-heterocyclic or ammonium cation and both [NTf2] and [OH] anions showed substantially improved performance over previous fluids exhibiting directional solubility. We found that a delicate balance exists between water rejection and absorption that is critical to DSE performance, and that using a mixture of ILs with hydrophilic anions to promote water extraction from saline and hydrophobic anions that enable water recovery lead to improved fresh water yield and ion rejection. 
  2. The identification and characterization of choline-based ILs bearing both [NTf2] and [OH] anions as mixed DSE TSILs that substantially outperformed previous fluid designs. These results support our hypothesis that a delicate balance exists between the hydrophobic and hydrophilic potential of ILs and their individual components to promote the directional solvation of fresh water from saturated aqueous NaCl solutions of varying concentrations. 
  3. The design of TSILs that showed efficacy in desalinating hyper-salinity aqueous NaCl solutions near saturation levels (ca. ~25%).
  4. The development of advanced analytical tools, including variable temperature NMR and MS, enabled an accurate assessment of purity and composition for previously unknown ILs. This work is critical to our efforts toward elucidating an accurate structure-function relationship between directional solubility, ion rejection, and fresh water yield that will form the framework for subsequent IL designs.
  5. The identification of hydrogen bonds, hydrophobic repulsion and electrostatic interactions between TSILs, water and natural salt ions that influence competing solubilities, such as the insolubility of natural ions in ILs, the temperature-dependent solubility of water in ILs and the insolubility of ILs in water, served to validate our hypothesis is that future molecular designs must rely on a balance of these architectural features.

A systematic molecular level study and understanding of complex and inter-dependent solubilities as applied to membrane-less water desalination processes constitutes the primary objective of this project. The findings that resulted from this funded project were disseminated in reputable, peer-reviewed journals recognized internationally as leaders in their respective areas, invited seminars, and contributions to discipline-specific and broadly themed science and engineering conferences. The significant results we obtained over the course of this study provided the framework for subsequent experimentation on the design and development of new fluids with direct applications toward interrogating a variety of biological and engineering research questions. The personnel outcomes associated with this award include the completion of or work toward four doctoral theses, and enabled five undergraduates at the University of Notre Dame to gain valuable research experience that will serve them throughout their future research and medical careers. The broad educational outcomes and outreach objectives that were achieved throughout the execution of this project included community outreach to area high schools designed to encourage collegiate pursuits.
